channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Bishop Mariann Budde tells NPR 'I won't apologize' for sermon addressing Trump
item.description: The Episcopal bishop of Washington spoke with NPR to discuss her sermon addressing President Trump and why she asked him to have mercy.
item.content:encoded:
The Episcopal bishop of Washington spoke with NPR to discuss her sermon addressing President Trump and why she asked him to have mercy.

(Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)
item.dc:creator: Alana Wise

item.title: They made a post-apocalyptic Sundance film. Then their homes burned
item.description: The zombie apocalypse film Didn't Die was made amid the devastation of the COVID-19 pandemic and upheaval in Hollywood. The filmmakers lost their homes – but are still sharing their movie at Sundance.
item.content:encoded:
The zombie apocalypse film Didn't Die was made amid the devastation of the COVID-19 pandemic and upheaval in Hollywood. The filmmakers lost their homes – but are still sharing their movie at Sundance.

(Image credit: Arthur Mola)
item.dc:creator: Mandalit del Barco

item.title: Congress clears GOP-led immigration enforcement bill, with Democrats on board
item.description: The House voted 263 to 156 to approve the Laken Riley act, sending the measure to Trump for his signature. The measure would make it easier for federal immigration officials to detain and deport those without legal status who are charged with specific crimes.
item.content:encoded:
The House voted 263 to 156 to approve the Laken Riley act, sending the measure to Trump for his signature. The measure would make it easier for federal immigration officials to detain and deport those without legal status who are charged with specific crimes.

(Image credit: J. Scott Applewhite)
item.dc:creator: Ximena Bustillo

item.title: DOJ threatens to prosecute local officials for resisting immigration enforcement
item.description: In a new memo, a Justice Department official seeks to realign the department's positions on immigration with President Trump's executive actions — and threatens local officials who don't cooperate.
item.content:encoded:
In a new memo, a Justice Department official seeks to realign the department's positions on immigration with President Trump's executive actions — and threatens local officials who don't cooperate.

(Image credit: Pool/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Joel Rose

item.title: Does Hamas Still Rule Gaza?
item.description: Israel vowed to remove Hamas from power when it went to war in Gaza, following the attacks on Israel in October, 2023. With a temporary ceasefire in place we're able to see if they've reached that goal and it seems Hamas is still deeply entrenched in Gaza. We'll hear more about who is taking charge as the dust settles and what the future of governance in the territory might be.
item.content:encoded: Israel vowed to remove Hamas from power when it went to war in Gaza, following the attacks on Israel in October, 2023. With a temporary ceasefire in place we're able to see if they've reached that goal and it seems Hamas is still deeply entrenched in Gaza. We'll hear more about who is taking charge as the dust settles and what the future of governance in the territory might be.
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre

item.title: Netflix raises monthly fees after a record jump in new subscribers
item.description: The company says it added 19 million new subscribers during the last quarter of 2024, fueled by live events and new shows. Netflix is also raising subscriptions by $1 to $2 per month in the U.S.
item.content:encoded:
The company says it added 19 million new subscribers during the last quarter of 2024, fueled by live events and new shows. Netflix is also raising subscriptions by $1 to $2 per month in the U.S.

(Image credit: Mario Tama)
item.dc:creator: Manuela López Restrepo

item.title: Assessing Trump's claim that U.S. pays 'unfair' share of dues to WHO
item.description: While signing the order to end U.S. membership in the World Health Organization, the President spoke of the disparity between contributions from the U.S. and China. Here's how WHO funding works.
item.content:encoded:
While signing the order to end U.S. membership in the World Health Organization, the President spoke of the disparity between contributions from the U.S. and China. Here's how WHO funding works.

(Image credit: Fabrice Coffrini)
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: Federal health agencies told to halt all external communications
item.description: In a memo obtained by NPR, acting Health Secretary Dorothy Fink forbade staff from public communications on most matters until Feb. 1, unless they get express approval from "a presidential appointee."
item.content:encoded:
In a memo obtained by NPR, acting Health Secretary Dorothy Fink forbade staff from public communications on most matters until Feb. 1, unless they get express approval from "a presidential appointee."

(Image credit: Sarah L. Voisin/The Washington Post)
item.dc:creator: Gabrielle Emanuel

item.title: The waiting stinks, but Sydney may soon enjoy the aroma of its 'corpse flower'
item.description: The flower's Latin name translates as "giant, misshapen penis." But it's better known to locals as "Putricia." Royal Botanical Garden Sydney has even set up a livestream in anticipation.
item.content:encoded:
The flower's Latin name translates as "giant, misshapen penis." But it's better known to locals as "Putricia." Royal Botanical Garden Sydney has even set up a livestream in anticipation.

(Image credit: Lisa Maree Williams)
item.dc:creator: Scott Neuman

item.title: When Ichiro retired, his records felt 'small' compared to the emotional moments
item.description: Ichiro Suzuki's career was full of hitting streaks, All-Star Games and Gold Glove awards. But all that paled compared to moments with fans like his farewell at the Tokyo Dome in 2019, he said.
item.content:encoded:
Ichiro Suzuki's career was full of hitting streaks, All-Star Games and Gold Glove awards. But all that paled compared to moments with fans like his farewell at the Tokyo Dome in 2019, he said.

(Image credit: Steph Chambers)
item.dc:creator: Becky Sullivan
